Always replace the current state with the new state.

leadingComments.value: Always replace the current state with the new state.

trailingComments.value: Set the pending flag indicating that this action has been scheduled, or
has recursively rescheduled itself.

leadingComments.value: Set the pending flag indicating that this action has been scheduled, or
has recursively rescheduled itself.

trailingComments.value: Important implementation note:
Actions only execute once by default, unless rescheduled from within the
scheduled callback. This allows us to implement single and repeat
actions via the same code path, without adding API surface area, as well
as mimic traditional recursion but across asynchronous boundaries.
However, JS runtimes and timers distinguish between intervals achieved by
serial `setTimeout` calls vs. a single `setInterval` call. An interval of
serial `setTimeout` calls can be individually delayed, which delays
scheduling the next `setTimeout`, and so on. `setInterval` attempts to
guarantee the interval callback will be invoked more precisely to the
interval period, regardless of load.
Therefore, we use `setInterval` to schedule single and repeat actions.
If the action reschedules itself with the same delay, the interval is not
canceled. If the action doesn't reschedule, or reschedules with a
different delay, the interval will be canceled after scheduled callback
execution.

leadingComments.value: Important implementation note:
Actions only execute once by default, unless rescheduled from within the
scheduled callback. This allows us to implement single and repeat
actions via the same code path, without adding API surface area, as well
as mimic traditional recursion but across asynchronous boundaries.
However, JS runtimes and timers distinguish between intervals achieved by
serial `setTimeout` calls vs. a single `setInterval` call. An interval of
serial `setTimeout` calls can be individually delayed, which delays
scheduling the next `setTimeout`, and so on. `setInterval` attempts to
guarantee the interval callback will be invoked more precisely to the
interval period, regardless of load.
Therefore, we use `setInterval` to schedule single and repeat actions.
If the action reschedules itself with the same delay, the interval is not
canceled. If the action doesn't reschedule, or reschedules with a
different delay, the interval will be canceled after scheduled callback
execution.

trailingComments.value: If this action has already an async Id, don't request a new one.

leadingComments.value: If this action has already an async Id, don't request a new one.
If this action is rescheduled with the same delay time, don't clear the interval id.

trailingComments.value: Otherwise, if the action's delay time is different from the current delay,
clear the interval id

leadingComments.value: Otherwise, if the action's delay time is different from the current delay,
clear the interval id
Dequeue if the action didn't reschedule itself. Don't call
unsubscribe(), because the action could reschedule later.
For example:
scheduler.schedule(function doWork(counter) {
/* ... I'm a busy worker bee ... */
var originalAction = this;
/* wait 100ms before rescheduling the action */
setTimeout(function () {
originalAction.schedule(counter + 1);

comments.value:
*
 * We need this JSDoc comment for affecting ESDoc.
 * @ignore
 * @extends {Ignored}
Always replace the current state with the new state.
Set the pending flag indicating that this action has been scheduled, or
has recursively rescheduled itself.
Important implementation note:
Actions only execute once by default, unless rescheduled from within the
scheduled callback. This allows us to implement single and repeat
actions via the same code path, without adding API surface area, as well
as mimic traditional recursion but across asynchronous boundaries.
However, JS runtimes and timers distinguish between intervals achieved by
serial `setTimeout` calls vs. a single `setInterval` call. An interval of
serial `setTimeout` calls can be individually delayed, which delays
scheduling the next `setTimeout`, and so on. `setInterval` attempts to
guarantee the interval callback will be invoked more precisely to the
interval period, regardless of load.
Therefore, we use `setInterval` to schedule single and repeat actions.
If the action reschedules itself with the same delay, the interval is not
canceled. If the action doesn't reschedule, or reschedules with a
different delay, the interval will be canceled after scheduled callback
execution.
If this action has already an async Id, don't request a new one.
If this action is rescheduled with the same delay time, don't clear the interval id.
Otherwise, if the action's delay time is different from the current delay,
clear the interval id
Dequeue if the action didn't reschedule itself. Don't call
unsubscribe(), because the action could reschedule later.
For example:
scheduler.schedule(function doWork(counter) {
/* ... I'm a busy worker bee ... */
var originalAction = this;
/* wait 100ms before rescheduling the action */
setTimeout(function () {
originalAction.schedule(counter + 1);
# sourceMappingURL=AsyncAction.js.map
